Key Word Index-Salvia
miltiorrhiza; Labiatae; pigment; diterpene; o-naphthaquinone; tanshindiol A; tanshindiol
B; tanshindiol C, nortanshinone; 3a-hydroxytanshinone
IIA.
Abstract-Five
new o-naphthaquinone diterpenes, tanshindiol A, tanshindiol B, tanshindiol C, nortanshinone and
3a-hydroxytanshinone HA, have been isolated from the roots of Saluia miltiorrhiza as minor components. Their relative
stereochemistries have been established on the basis of spectral and chemical evidence.
text.body:
INTRODUCIION
'Dan-Shen', the dried roots of Salvia miltiorrhiza Bunge, is
a clinically important Chinese drug in the treatment of
heart disease. Many chemists have studied the physiologi-
cally active constituents of this drug and have isolated
more than 16 orange-red crystalline pigments, abietanoids
[l, 2 and refs. therein]. Most abietanoids have either a
furano-ortho-naphthaquinone
or a furano-para-naphtha-
quinone skeleton and are classified biogenetically
as diterpenes. In the course of our search for physiologi-
cally active substances in Chinese drugs [3 and refs.
therein], we have isolated five new pigments, tanshindiol
A (l), tanshindiol B (2), tanshindiol C (3), nortanshinone
(4) and 3cr-hydroxytanshinone IIA (5), from Dan-Shen as
minor components. This paper describes the isolation and
characterization of these pigments.
Tanshindiols B (2) and C (3) had the same molecular
formula, ClsH160s (m/z 312 [Ml'), and their spectral
data were quite similar to each other, indicating that they
must be stereoisomers. Thus, in addition to each tertiary
hydroxyl group, 2 had a secondary axial hydroxyl group
cS3.98 (lH, dd, J = 4.8, 2.9 Hz)] and 3 had a secondary
equatorial one cS3.96 (lH, dd, J = 4.0, 12 Hz)]. In fact,
oxidation of either 2 or 3 with sodium periodate gave the
same product (8). 8 had an acetophenone-type methyl
ketone moiety c62.61 (3H, s)] and a phenylpropion-
aldehyde moiety. The presence of the latter moiety
(Ar-CH&H&HO)
in 8 was established by the

RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Repeated column chromatography of the ethanolic
extract of Dan-Shen on silica gel afforded five new
abietanoids (l-S), in addition to many known abietanoids
which are described in the Experimental.
Tanshindiol A (l), orange-red needles, C1sH1605, gave
rise to spectra which were similar to those of tanshinone
IIA (6) [4,5]. However, notable differences between 1 and
6 were seen with regard to the following points. The
'H NMR spectrum of 6 had a singlet due to a geminal
dimethyl group at 61.30 [631.9 (q +q) and 34.9 (s) in the
13C NMR spectrum (Table l)] and the IR spectrum of 6
showed no hydroxyl band. On the other hand, 1 had two
hydroxyl groups instead of a geminal dimethyl group.
One of them was a primary alcohol attached to a
tetrasubstituted carbon ES3.60 (2H, s); m/z 281 [M
-3 l] '1 and the other was a tertiary alcohol attached to
the same carbon. This was further confirmed by acety-
lation of 1 with acetic anhydride-pyridine
to give the
corresponding monoacetate (7) [v3500 and 1725 cm-';
62.14 (3H, s), and 4.22 (2H, s); 669.6 (t)and 71.4 (s)]. From
the above results, the structure of tanshindiol A can be
represented as 1.

multiplet at 63.32 and the near singlet at 69.85 to collapse

63.32 the multiplet at 62.90 became a near singlet. The
stereochemistries of the two vicinal hydroxyl groups in 2
and 3 were determined on the basis of the following
chemical evidence. Treatment of 2 with acetone in the
presence of anhydrous cupric sulphate resulted in the
recovery of the starting material, but treatment of 3 under
the same conditions readily afforded the corresponding
acetonide (9). The structures of tanshindiols B and C can
therefore be represented as 2 and 3, respectively, including
the stereochemistries of the two vicinal hydroxyl groups.
Nortanshinone (4), C,,H,104,
gave rise to spectra
similar to those of tanshinone IIA (6). Moreover, 4 had
one arylic carbonyl group [S 197.3 (s)] instead of a geminal
dimethyl group in addition to two orthoquinone car-
bony1 groups [S 175.5 (s) and 182.8 ($1. The location of the
arylic carbonyl group was assigned by analysis of the
'H NMR spectrum with the aid of double resonance
experiments. On irradiation at 62.12, the multiplets at
6 2.7 1 and 3.46 were changed to sharp singlets. The signal
at 6 2.12 was changed to a triplet on irradiation at 6 2.71 as
well as at 3.46. Furthermore, the doublet at 67.96 in 1 was
shifted to 68.37 in the 'H NMR spectrum of 4. This
downfield shift seemed to be due to the anisotropic effect
of the carbonyl group. From these results, the structure of
nortanshinone can be represented as 4. In addition,
tanshindiol A (1) was subjected to oxidation using sodium
periodate to afford a carbonyl compound which was
identical to nortanshinone (4).
The last pigment, 3a-hydroxytanshinone
IIA (S),
CigHlsO,, had a geminal dimethyl group C61.33 (6H, s)]
and a secondary hydroxyl group [a 3.67 (1 H, m)], which
was readily acetylated by acetic anhydride-pyridine
to
give the corresponding acetate (10) cS2.05 (3H, s) and 5.00
(1 H, t, J = 4.9 Hz)]. The presence of the partial structure
ECH2-CHI-CH-~
in 5 was established by the follow-
ing experiments. On irradiation of 10 at 65.00, the
multiplet at 62.03 changed to a triplet, and then the
multiplet at 63.32 as well as that at 65.00 changed to a
singlet on irradiation at 62.03. Finally, the multiplet at
62.03 changed to a doublet on irradiation at 63.32. In
1968, hydroxytanshinone
II (11) having a secondary
hydroxyl group at C-l was reported by Kalcisawa et al.
[S]. The physical data of 5 are clearly different from those
of 11. Therefore, the hydroxyl group in 5 must be located
at C-3. This was also confirmed by the 'H NMR spectra,
which showed the signals due to the benzylic methylene
protons at 63.26 (2H) in 5 and at 63.32 (2H) in 10,
respectively. From the above results, the structure of 3a-
hydroxytanshinone IIA can be represented as 5.
With the exception of 4, we have not established the
absolute configurations of the new pigments (l-5).
EXPERIMENTAL
Mps: uncorr; 'H NMR (100 and 60 MHz) and 13C NMR
(25 MHz): CDCI, unless stated otherwise, TM.9 as internal
standard, IR: KBr; MS: direct inlet system.
Extraction and separation. Dan-Shen (ca 120 kg) from the
Shandong Province (China) was mechanically crushed and
extracted with hot 95% EtOH. The cont. extract (1.2 kg) was
treated with CsHs to give a C,H6-soluble fraction (ca 800 g) and
a CdH,-insoluble fraction (ca 400 g).
The former fraction was chromatographed on silica gel and

eluted successively with C6He and CIH,-CHCI,-MeOH
(9: 1:0.5). Each fraction obtained was rechromatographed on
silica gel using a gradient of CHCI&IezCO to afford five known
pigments, tanshinone IIA (78 g), tanshinone I (6 g), methylene-
tanshiquinone (2 g), cryptotanshinone
(2 g) and dihydro-
tanshinone I (1 g) as crystals, respectively. The mother liquor of
tanshinone I from CHCI,-MeOH
was coned and further
separated by CC on silica gel using CHCI, containing an
increasing amount of MezCO to give nortanshinone (4) (101 mg).
The CeH,-insoluble fraction, which was soluble in a
mixture of C6Hs-MeOH (9:1), was subjected to dry CC on
silica gel. The very polar fraction (ca 260g) eluted with
&H,-MeOH-formamide
(7: 3 : 0.5) after elution with C6H6 was
rechromatographed on polyamide powder using 95 y0 EtOH to
afford a mixture of reddish pigments (120 g). The mixture was
separated further by CC on sil&a gel using CHzClz-EtOAc (3: 1)
to afford four crude pigments (1, 2,3 and 5). These pigments were
purified by prep. TLC on silica gel (CHzClz-EtOAcMeOH,
15: 5: 1) followed by recrystalization from CHCl,-MeOH to
afford pure pigments, 1 (9Omg), 2 (9Omg), 3 (30mg) and 5
(85 mg), respectively.
